Frank.Action: Drives EMS vehicle with confidence, equipped with professional gear and maintaining alertness for hidden danger.
Arrives promptly and prepared at emergency scene, calmly directs crowd to move back and locates the correct apartment.
Describes moments of high skill and cool authority in his work, where his hands move with speed and skill beyond himself.
Admits to losing control over the past year, not having saved anyone for months and feeling the need for rest.
Quickly organizes the emergency scene by asking for the stairs and directing bystanders to move back.
Carries necessary emergency equipment efficiently alongside his partner Larry.
Reassures John Burke with 'We'll do all we can' and actively works to save Mr. Burke despite grim circumstances.
Focuses on medical interventions in a professional, calm manner, showing respect for the patient and family by continuing efforts despite difficulty.
Mentally drifts to spiritual thoughts about death and spirits, indicating empathy and sensitivity to the emotional weight of the situation.
Asks for music that the deceased liked to comfort the relatives.
Shows empathy by noticing Mary's pain and the atmosphere around her.
Sincerely tries to save Mr. Burke despite the hopeless situation.
Takes Mary’s arm gently and encourages her to help her family despite her hesitation.
Flips lights and siren on to show urgency for the family, even though it’s too late to help the patient.
Hangs IV bags, replugs EKG wires that have come loose, ensuring patient monitoring continues uninterrupted.
Takes Mary by the arm and firmly but compassionately encourages her to help her family, showing emotional intelligence and leadership.
Flips lights and siren on when driving behind the family, understanding the importance of appearance and urgency even if it won’t save the patient.
Mentions needing to concentrate because his mind tends to wander, acknowledging a potential distraction during critical tasks.
Insists to Griss to let them into the ER despite the crowd and backup, showing persistence and concern for Burke's condition.
Moves quickly through the crowded ER without delay or hesitation, following Nurse Constance's instruction to keep moving, showing some respect for hospital protocol.
Pumps Ambu-bag to maintain patient's breathing while advocating to get inside ER despite crowd and resistance.
Wheels Burke inside the crowded and chaotic ER efficiently with a colleague.
Does not hesitate or show confusion in a high-pressure medical emergency situation.
Insists on staying with his patient despite pleas for water, prioritizing duty over compassion in that moment.
Advocates to nurse to accept patient at the crowded hospital because patient wanted to come there, showing respect for patient's wishes and some empathy.
Correctly updates Hazmat that the patient 'got better' despite earlier being pronounced dead.
Seemingly passive while Hazmat explains complex critical care situations and treatments, with no indication of Frank taking initiative or contributing.
Pushes stretcher down Skid Row, passes Nurse Constance who is harshly reprimanding a patient; Frank does not engage or intervene.
Responds to Mary Burke with a stock reply 'He's very very sick' rather than offering empathy or personal concern.
Acts quickly to move Mary Burke outside, showing concern for a tense situation and attempting to de-escalate.
Notices Big Feet helping Noel, allowing assistance and ensuring Noel is untied before continuing.
Pushes stretcher away calmly from a chaotic scene to continue work without hesitation.
Responds to Mary's recognition of Noel with a stock reply instead of acknowledging or elaborating.
Quickly suggests moving outside after Noel disrupts the stretcher, showing situational awareness and urgency.
Fumbles in his pocket, finds a tissue, gives it to Mary when she starts to cry.
Watches Noel and Mary hug, realizing this is what he should have done for her.
Tells Mary he wouldn't give Noel water because the doctor thinks Noel has a rare disorder.
Turns to look at the pregnant woman, showing momentary recognition and concern.
Hits the ambulance siren to warn pimps to move away, protecting others nearby.
Shows little interest in food or team bonding, focusing instead on his own thoughts and emotional state.
Does not immediately correct Larry's criticism about stopping for hookers, appears emotionally withdrawn.
Stops to look at the women on the street, engages momentarily, does not maintain focus on the task at hand.
Uses the ambulance siren appropriately to clear the way from potential threats.
Acknowledges hunger but pushes it aside, indicating some self-neglect and lack of self-care affecting performance.
Responds reasonably and calmly to Larry's frustrations without escalating conflict.
Reflects on the spirits and suffering of the dead with a somber, empathetic tone.
Warns Larry not to push him and resists optimistic view on fires, emphasizing tragedy.
Understands and accepts the emotional toll of the job, recognizes the psychological hauntings of his work but still shows awareness of his limits.
Hesitates and resists radio communication as suggested by Larry, showing reluctance to engage fully despite the demand of the job.
Reluctantly answers the radio call for Mr. Oh despite reservations.
Downplays the seriousness of Mr. Oh's condition, calling him 'just a drunk' and treating him dismissively.
Crouches over Mr. Oh, tries to pull his pants up and helps him into his wheelchair despite Mr. Oh's condition and discomfort.
Responds promptly to the street people's concern and helps get Mr. Oh to the ambulance.
Leans out the window to avoid bad smell rather than interacting with those around.
Crouches over Oh and tries to pull his pants over to preserve his dignity before moving him.
Lifts Oh carefully and sets him into the wheelchair despite Oh's poor condition and stumbling.
Flips on the ambulance top lights and urges Larry to go faster.
Frank and Larry wheel Mr. Oh outside despite resistance from staff; showing compassion toward a homeless/inebriated patient.
Offers Mary a light for her cigarette and shares a brief moment of connection with her.
Makes a gentle, hopeful comment ('You never know') when Mary talks about her dying father, showing empathy and support.
Secretly pleased as they wheel Mr. Oh outside after being denied a stretcher, showing some initiative and compassion under challenging conditions.
Offers Mary Burke a light and shows empathy and conversational skill, though this is more emotional intelligence than competence.
Does not intervene when Nurse Crupp refuses a stretcher, choosing to quietly comply and manage the situation by wheeling Mr. Oh outside, indicating practical problem-solving.
Says 'At least he's got people around him' acknowledging others' support during a difficult time.
Encourages Mary to take her mother home and get some rest, showing concern and practical advice.
Counters Larry's relaxed attitude by insisting on running calls, showing responsibility for others' care.
Notices Rose, the homeless man not breathing, expresses concern and suggests going back to the hospital, admitting he is not feeling well.
Agrees with Larry’s comment about having a good job despite his own reservations, indicates some resignation.
Drinks every day, feels haunted by patients dying, expresses despair but continues responding to calls.
Tries to rest when calls are fewer, shows fatigue.
Promptly answers radio dispatch and reacts quickly to emergency call.
Turns down radio volume and leans back trying to rest during slow calls, showing awareness of his own fatigue but ability to manage downtime.
Answers radio call promptly and communicates clearly with dispatcher, indicating alertness and procedural knowledge.
Bangs steering wheel to wake up partner and convey urgency, demonstrating initiative and decisiveness.
Exhibits self-doubt and despair over not having saved anyone recently and frequent drinking, showing diminished confidence and impaired coping potentially affecting competence.
Calms Noel down and tries to talk him out of self-harm, explaining options and offering help sincerely.
Rolls up window to avoid blood splatter but returns quickly to attend to Noel despite getting hurt.
Questions Larry sarcastically about Noel's sanity, showing some skepticism rather than open empathy.
Calms a potentially dangerous situation by talking Noel down from self-harm, showing knowledge of Noel's condition and hospital procedures.
Rolls up the window after being splattered with blood, effectively protecting himself.
Questions Larry's simplistic judgment, showing deeper insight into Noel's mental state.
Takes a careful and patient approach instead of escalating violence, despite provocation.
Tells Walls that it's not worth it to hurt Noel because he's surrendering.
Verbally pleads with Walls not to beat Noel.
Intervenes verbally to try to de-escalate Tom Walls from attacking Noel, saying 'It's not worth it, Tom. He's surrendering.'
Steps over the injured Noel and closes the bus doors, facilitating quick departure from the scene.
Drops to his knees besides the injured drug dealer and asks where he was hit, showing attention and care.
Tells the drug dealer 'You're not going to die.' offering hope and reassurance.
Tells Noel to 'shut up' harshly and bluntly, prioritizing the drug dealer's survival over Noel's feelings.
Refuses to hold the drug dealer's hand, telling Noel to hold it instead, indicating emotional distance.
Speaks calmly to the drug dealer that they are at the hospital 'It's all right. We're here...'
Reassures a boy they have arrived at the hospital ('It's all right. We're here.')
Calmly declares the boy is not breathing and instructs to call a code
Offers a cigarette to Mary Burke showing a small friendly gesture
Makes a lighthearted comment about smoking and whiskey with Mary
Answers Mary's direct questions about the dead boy frankly and without evasion
Exhibits resignation and no apparent emotional openness about the tragedy
Feels for pulse, listens with stethoscope, recognizes patient is not breathing, instructs partner to call a code, and assists in removing the dead boy from the bus.
Finishes his report efficiently, hands a copy to the clerk, and surveys the emergency room surroundings calmly.
Steps outside to smoke a cigarette and casually jokes about smoking and drinking.
Responds clearly and succinctly to Mary about the condition and death of the boy without hesitation.
Engages in light banter with Mary but exhibits no signs of losing focus or professionalism.
Tries to say the right thing to Mary during a difficult moment, showing empathy.
Gently persuades Mrs. Burke to go home and assures her that her husband will be cared for.
Offers to help Mrs. Burke by personally escorting her back home with Larry.
Tries to comfort Mary and Mrs. Burke, suggests practical actions such as telling Mrs. Burke to go home and offering to help escort her back.
Looks at Mary, trying to say the right thing but does not articulate anything meaningful.
Reflects thoughtfully and poetically on the profound impact of saving lives, showing emotional sensitivity and appreciation for human connection.
Lives a minimal, somewhat isolated lifestyle with aluminum foil blocking sunlight, drinks whiskey alone, indicating possible emotional withdrawal or detachment.
Apologizes sincerely to the Captain and tells him not to take the firing too hard.
Acknowledges his own shortcomings (lateness, sickness) without making excuses.
Encourages the Captain to be strong and take responsibility despite external pressures.
Repeatedly late and sick for shifts affecting team reliability.
Repeatedly late and absent for shifts, acknowledged by captain; no excuse beyond being 'sick'.
Accepts impending termination calmly and without argument; shows some emotional control.
Attempts to rationalize or convince Captain Barney to be strong and take responsibility for firing.
Greets dispatcher Love warmly after not hearing from her for months.
Makes a lighthearted joke about Marcus's blind date with Love, fostering friendly conversation.
Expresses skepticism about being fired, showing vulnerability.
Mentions 'ghosts' implying internal struggles but opens up to Marcus.
Kneels beside IB Bangin, carefully assesses his condition, hopeful despite Marcus' conclusion.
Kneels beside IB Bangin, takes a pulse and correctly realizes the apparent lack of pulse is due to makeup; uses a flashlight to check the pupil.
Whispers 'He's not dead' despite the grim situation and Marcus's declaration.
Opens the drug box, prepares and injects Narcon to save IB Bangin.
Gives Marcus the high sign to proceed, showing teamwork and trust.
Guides IB Bangin to the door with the Girlfriend, showing care and assistance.
Inquires about the condition of the patient he brought in, showing concern for the patient's wellbeing.
Acknowledges the patient's ongoing struggle and treatment details, showing empathy.
Nods quietly upon hearing about the patient's family and situation, showing somber understanding.
Calls the patient's daughter to share early hopeful news about her father, showing concern and sincerity.
Compliments Mary’s changed appearance in a kind and reassuring way.
Shows empathy and communicates clearly and supportively with Mary about her father's condition, providing hopeful but cautious information.
Recognizes Marcus's story and engages in a casual, attentive conversation while on duty, showing awareness and memory.
Decides to stop the ambulance voluntarily to follow up on a patient's family situation, demonstrating initiative and concern beyond strict protocol.
Offers Mary a ride when no taxis are available, showing consideration and kindness.
Speaks gently and supportively about Mary's father and her difficult family relationship.
Invites Mary to share a meal with him despite his own hunger, indicating friendliness and sincerity.
Suggests Mary and others go outside to wait until Burke's agitation passes, providing space and calm.
Explains to Mary the reason for her father's sedation and restraints with understanding and empathy.
Internally wishes to watch Mary from multiple angles simultaneously, showing concern for her well-being.
Suggests going outside to wait until the patient’s agitation passes, helping to de-escalate a tense situation.
Explains to Mary why the patient is sedated and why the movement is a good sign, showing understanding and ability to communicate medical conditions calmly.
Mentally wishes to be in three places at once to watch Mary from different angles, indicating concern but possible distraction or inability to fully focus.
Admits to a difficult past relationship with sincerity and some self-blame.
Describes coping with hardship by blocking it out but recalling moments of goodness, showing emotional transparency.
Responds modestly to Mary’s suggestion he might have helped her before, showing humility and sincerity.
Hands the last slice of pizza to a colleague Griss, indicating generosity and concern.
Asks Griss to look after Mary’s father, showing care and trustworthiness.
Responds calmly and honestly when asked about his personal life; acknowledges difficulties without evasion.
Describes coping mechanism of emotionally fencing off trauma similar to trained professionals.
Shows attentiveness and responsibility by reminding Griss to look after Mary.
Maintains composure amid chaotic ER environment.
Does not elaborate or take initiative to improve or change his circumstances or relationships despite acknowledging personal fault.
Shows understanding and tolerance by acknowledging his role as 'a grief mop' and bearing witness rather than solely focusing on heroic life-saving, demonstrating humility and presence.
Makes a joking remark about rule number three: don't get involved with dispatchers named Love, indicating some lightheartedness and friendly rapport.
Passively observes the chaotic and painful night scenes without direct intervention, mainly showing up rather than actively comforting, which could indicate limited overt warmth.
Recalls training and acknowledges the unpredictability of the street, indicating understanding of the limits of formal skills.
Mentally shifts perspective from trying to save lives to bearing witness and providing emotional support, showing realistic self-awareness.
Lets mind wander and fails to engage actively with Marcus or the situation, indicating possible disengagement or lack of focus.
Defends the working girl by saying 'She's no whore, Marcus.'
Hears 'Rose' faintly say 'Why did you kill me, Frank?' and replies 'I didn't kill you.'
States 'I need a drink, that's all.' after a stressful moment.
Asserts firmly that the woman was not a whore when Marcus makes a disparaging comment.
Hears 'Rose' faintly accusing him of killing her but denies it, showing awareness and mental clarity.
States he needs a drink in the midst of a work shift, indicating possible reliance on alcohol or emotional coping that may undermine professional capability.
Engages patiently with Maria and Carlos despite language barrier, tries to reassure Carlos with 'You can trust me on this one.'
Shows concern and urgency to help Maria, calls for backup quickly.
Uses some humor or sarcastic undertone with Marcus ('Thanks for the translation.')
Accurately diagnoses Maria's condition despite language barriers and impossible statements from Carlos.
Recognizes the severity of the situation and immediately calls for backup.
Calmly instructs others on how to assist despite high stress and screaming.
Rushing past Nurse Constance carrying a newborn to get help and communicating relevant information quickly under pressure.
Looks at the flatline monitor and backs away, showing emotional impact of the loss.
Walking away without noticing Noel who politely asks for water, failing to respond to a dying man's simple request.
Rushing past nurse carrying a newborn with a pulse; provides info about the breech twins and the other child being stable; responds to emergency calmly.
Looks at the flatline monitor and backs away, then walks off distracted and bumps into Noel's gurney instead of maintaining situational awareness.
Shares a quiet moment with Marcus celebrating their work saving a baby, shows camaraderie.
Dismisses the significance of saving the baby initially and seems emotionally closed off.
Calmly acknowledges the end of a difficult night with three jobs completed, prepares drinks, and maintains composure after stressful calls.
Expresses dislike for vodka but continues drinking, suggesting possible reliance on alcohol despite knowing its effects.
Refuses to engage in optimism after saving a baby, indicating emotional burnout or detachment rather than reflective judgment.
Quits the ambulance after a crash, leaves without helping Marcus or staying with the team.
Says goodbye to Noel in a seemingly casual manner, possibly indicating detachment.
Shows concern by following Mary Burke as she runs off, keeping his distance but attentive.
Covers his face and screams during ambulance crash, then immediately assesses no one is hurt and climbs out.
Quits abruptly after crash, leaves partner and disabled vehicle, walking away from emergency situation.
After leaving ambulance, observes surroundings and tries to engage with others (Griss) about a troubling situation, showing situational awareness.
Offers to wait outside the building to keep Mary safe despite the danger.
Insists on accompanying Mary inside the dangerous building to protect her.
Offers to accompany Mary, suggests caring actions like walking her home, encouraging rest and relaxation.
Follows Mary into a place despite being asked not to go inside, pushes past Kanita who says he can't go in.
Follows Mary into a risky environment despite warnings, insists on staying to support her.
Paces waiting outside, checks his watch, attempts to use the elevator to re-enter.
Pushes past Kanita despite her objections, enters restricted area without explicit permission.
Introduces himself politely to Coates.
Shows concern for Mary by insisting they leave and trying to rouse her.
Does not respond negatively or with hostility to Coates's reassurance and touch.
Introduces himself confidently to Coates, promptly asks for Mary, and attempts to take responsibility by trying to get Mary up and going despite her resistance.
Fails to convincingly calm Mary, who reacts violently and collapses unconscious, suggesting difficulty managing the situation effectively.
Accepts a pill reluctantly from Coates and drinks water when offered by Kanita.
Hesitates before taking the pill, seeming unsure about the offered help.
Expresses desire to leave, saying he just quit, showing withdrawal from the stressful situation.
Quit his job recognizing it is too stressful and intends to leave.
Hesitates before taking the pill offered by Coates, showing caution before accepting substances.
Passively accepts drug use and encouragement to take pills from Coates despite possible negative consequences.
Shows limited assertiveness; despite quitting and showing hesitation, ultimately complies with Coates’s push for drug use.
Kanita runs her hand across his shoulders, he responds by nodding and says 'Perfect' about her pulse; shares a moment of connection and calm with her.
Despite repeated failed attempts to intubate Rose and save her life, Frank persists, showing care and determination in a critical moment.
Gets pushed aside by Larry after failing to successfully intubate Rose, but continues to struggle and react emotionally to the situation.
Attempts to intubate Rose despite difficulty; persists trying to place tube correctly before Larry intervenes.
Fails to properly intubate Rose, repeatedly placing the tube in the stomach instead of the lungs, leading to failure.
In distress, physically supports Mary by carrying her fireman-style and catching her when she stumbles.
Continues following Mary and stays close to monitor her condition despite her protests.
Screams in pain and distress, showing vulnerability and emotional openness.
Follows Mary into her apartment and sits quietly despite her harsh words; allows the dog to lick his cheek while he rests, showing tolerance and calmness.
Acknowledges and introduces himself to the dog as 'a very close friend who loves animals,' indicating friendliness and sincerity.
Needs to sit down and appears mentally and physically exhausted, leaning into vulnerability without hostility or blame.
Asks to sit down, then slumps on the sofa and falls asleep despite the tense situation.
After waking, cautiously explores the dark apartment and activates lights to assess surroundings.
Turns up late to work but is not fired because Captain Barney lacks staff.
Jokes with Captain Barney about repercussions of being late and doubts there will be a tomorrow.
Walks with confidence toward the EMS vehicle despite it being a dented, old relic; signals 'be right back' before entering ER.
Does not directly intervene in a tense situation (Griss holding back angry man), just greeting allies instead.
Leans over patient Burke to check his pulse, showing attentiveness and care.
Steps back and asks intern Milagros to use defibrillator paddles, then reluctantly takes over himself and shocks patient as urged by family and medical staff.
Appears despondent and walks away after successful resuscitation, indicating emotional strain or detachment.
Examines patient carefully, monitors EKG, responds to patient's critical state by preparing to defibrillate.
Defers initial defibrillator use to intern Milagros, then reluctantly takes paddles and shocks patient as instructed.
Appears despondent and walks away immediately after successful shock, not engaging further in patient care.
Injects himself with drugs to cope, admits he's sick and struggling.
Engages in light banter and camaraderie with Walls, sharing jokes about coffee and their mission.
Withdraws mentally, somewhat despondent and distracted, not fully attentive to urgent situations.
Injects himself with vitamin B cocktail, glucose, and adrenaline to keep functioning during his EMS shift.
Appears despondent and distracted, not responding to a colleague's question and walking away.
Takes initiative to prepare medical equipment and administer oxygen in the ambulance despite personal struggles.
Expresses negativity and lack of motivation about sobriety and the mission, undermining confidence.
Pulls the IV needle out of his arm and looks for Band-aids, showing concern and readiness to care.
Effortlessly removes IV needle and looks for band-aids in the ambulance, shows familiarity with emergency procedures and environment.
Asks where band-aids are, indicating momentary uncertainty or minor lack of preparedness but within reasonable bounds.
Tries to convince Cut Wrists not to go through with his suicide attempt, harshly expressing disgust but ultimately wanting to save him.
Watches a hooker on the sidewalk, then decides to head out with Walls to respond to an emergency despite exhaustion.
Responds to dispatch with concern and readiness to help unconscious man by wheelchair.
Drives recklessly at high speed, indicating possible emotional distress or detachment.
Acknowledges the broken brakes but continues driving at high speed, indicating awareness and calculated risk-taking.
Engages confidently and quickly with the dispatcher about a critical emergency call, showing situational understanding.
Distracted by observing the hooker and punks before heading out, suggesting possible momentary detachment.
Immediately responds to emergency call, prepares to assist in a high-risk rescue situation without hesitation.
Coordinates pragmatically with team, showing concern for group safety and efficiency.
States 'Better bring it all' showing readiness and thoroughness in preparing equipment for rescue.
Recognizes the elevator is broken and decides to take the stairs, demonstrating practical problem-solving.
Chooses to go to the sixteenth floor alone, indicating confidence and willingness to take initiative.
Takes time to gently check on Coates' injury, speaks considerately to him despite the severity of the situation.
Looks over the balcony, assesses the situation, decides to head to the thirteenth floor promptly.
Engages with Walls to gather information about patients and their conditions.
Approaches Coates carefully, takes vital signs, checks abdomen for injury, asks if it hurts, showing medical skill.
Puts on oxygen mask while holding IV bag in his teeth, demonstrating multitasking under pressure.
Gently takes Coates' vital signs and reassures him that he will live.
Explains the procedure calmly to Coates to prepare him for discomfort.
Passes IV bag and physically supports Coates' head in a difficult moment.
Responds bluntly and without consolation about Kanita's death.
Admits to being tired and needing coffee when Coates jokes about delay.
Grabs and holds Coates tightly, preventing him from falling.
Helps Hazmat restrain Burke and manage his medical emergency.
Grabs and holds Coates tightly, preventing him from falling during a dangerous situation.
Helps Hazmat forcibly insert a bite stick to manage Burke’s ventilator and restraints.
Greets Mary Burke's family friends politely when introduced.
Offers Mary a cigarette and listens to her talk about personal matters.
Makes a lighthearted joke about following a patient with a defibrillator.
Avoids engaging deeply with Mary initially by saying he's going out for a smoke when she is introduced to her family.
Engages in a knowledgeable conversation about medical devices, asking how many times the patient was shocked and showing understanding of defibrillators and implants.
Greets family and friends of a patient calmly and appropriately, maintaining professionalism and empathy.
Steps aside to have a personal conversation with Mary, showing some social awareness but potentially avoiding direct communication with others.
Provides reassurance to Mary about another patient's condition despite limited information, showing confidence but possibly a lack of full knowledge.
Thanks Mary for letting him crash, says it was the best sleep he's had in months, and uses some of her soap.
Offers to bring Mary something back to eat (falafel or pizza).
Places his hand on Mary's shoulder and kisses her lightly despite her saying it's not a good time.
Expresses a fatalistic, inclusive statement: 'We're all dying, Mary Burke.'
Offers to bring Mary something to eat and accepts help graciously, showing social awareness and adaptability.
Remains silent when Mary asks if he saw 'him', showing possible emotional distance or withholding of information.
Handles the urgency of a new call calmly, gets ready quickly to respond.
Shows emotional impulsiveness by trying to kiss Mary despite the situation not being appropriate and her clear refusal.
Passes a pint of whiskey back and forth with Walls while working, jokingly suggests getting into fights and breaking windows out of restlessness and a need for distraction.
Expresses some sympathy or understanding by saying 'He's crazy. He can't help it.' about Noel.
Questions Walls' plan as 'ridiculous', showing reluctance or skepticism.
Questions the strategy suggested by Walls, showing skepticism toward a planned approach.
Follows Walls' instructions and engages with the target despite expressing doubt.
Encourages and engages in playful camaraderie with Noel, recalling a shared baseball story while taking the bat to participate.
Forgets Walls' plan and disrupts the situation by smashing a car window, causing frustration for Walls.
Relinquishes the bat initially, showing hesitation.
Forgets Walls' plan and gets distracted breaking car windows.
Takes initiative to enter alley and cautiously pursues suspect with flashlight.
Charges forward to stop Walls from beating Noel and tries to save Noel, showing concern and urgency.
Stands back and watches Walls hitting Noel like a detached observer before intervening.
Charges forward into Walls, disarms him, and quickly initiates emergency procedures on Noel, showing decisive action under pressure.
Commands Walls to get the medical kit and simultaneously plans to call for backup while attempting to save Noel, demonstrating situational awareness and leadership.
Stands back and watches Walls hitting Noel before intervening, indicating possible hesitation or delayed response in preventing violence.
Encourages Noel by saying 'You're going to make it!' and performs CPR, mouth-to-mouth resuscitation.
Carries IV bag while pushing Noel through ER, communicates calmly with Nurse Constance and Hazmat, showing cooperation and concern.
Checks on Burke's whereabouts and later enters room 212, seems respectful and solemn in moments with Burke.
Flips off life support machines while holding Burke's pulse and watching life leave him, then restarts machines upon hearing commotion.
Performs CPR on Noel promptly and with determination, showing skill and confidence in emergency medical procedures.
Responds concisely and accurately to Hazmat's questions, indicating awareness of the situation and clarity.
Notices the absence of Burke and inquires, demonstrating situational awareness and responsibility.
Flips off life support machines and alarms while holding Burke's pulse, then flips them back on upon hearing a commotion, showing controlled, knowledgeable handling of end-of-life procedures.
Performs futile CPR shocks on Burke despite knowing it's likely futile, fulfilling his role in a sincere, dutiful manner.
Nods to take on the difficult task of telling the family about the death, showing acceptance of a hard, empathetic responsibility.
Walks silently to Mary/Rose's apartment to inform them of the death, facing an emotionally charged moment without avoidance.
Says very little to Mary/Rose at the door, which results in a tense, darkened expression from Mary; his silence may imply emotional distance or difficulty connecting.
Informs Rose/Mary gently about her father's death and repeatedly apologizes.
Accepts invitation to come inside and allows Rose/Mary to comfort him, showing vulnerability and trust.
Explains the patient's death clearly and professionally, showing acceptance of medical facts.
Nods in understanding when given advice about keeping the body going until brain and heart recover.
Expresses sorrow but does not display hesitation or confusion about the situation.
